在美国，找到像新鲜爆米花，像地球一样闻起来的玉米饼，并支持墨西哥的小家庭农场，从来不容易。在某些城市中，您可以购买一袋新鲜MASA，适用于自制炸玉米饼，尽可能容易找到切片的面包。就在几年前，您唯一的优质玉米饼的选择是为了刷Web，为“附近的Tortillerías”进行“粉碎”或者在他们收到他们的泰奎罗。那我们是怎么来到这里的？
 “我们在第三波MASA的时代，这是100年的制作，”Jorge Gaviria说，这是指在美国的一个世纪进入Nixtamalized Masa，最终在我们当前的黄金时代。作为Masienda的Cofounter，墨西哥墨西哥玉米和高品质玉米饼装备的进口商，他已经赢得了MASA先驱的绰号，以享有MASA的复苏。他对复杂，芳香，泥土玉米的新需求，对第三波专业咖啡机芯的影响对我们的咖啡胃口的影响。 “关于这个过程的一丝不苟的采购，单一的，而且凝视正在发生在MASA中，”他说。 “这是同样的框架。”
  美国的第一波Masa是方便的，从Maseca的发明开始，1941年。在几十年之下，第二波砂浆玉米饼商店始于各国大型墨西哥移民群体。这些Tortillerías制作了美国商品田野的体面的Masa，并成为美国巴里奥斯的骨干。
  Masa的第三波是关于寻求来自墨西哥的小种植者最美味的玉米品种。在墨西哥州和墨西哥州墨西哥州的两个品牌 - 莫奥纳 - 通过从墨西哥的沉重的大袋到美国的巨型繁重的玉米，所有这些都是严重玉米饼的名义。截至目前，这些是唯一有足够联系的墨西哥农民的公司，以确保圆形玉米的一致供应。但他们并不孤单地建立这一波浪。在波特兰，俄勒冈州的三个姐妹尼克萨尔和洛杉矶的真理有机物等三个姐妹，以及奥斯汀的餐厅，正在与美国农民一起使用国内玉米来制造最好的Masa。
   真正的Nixtamapized Masa之间的差异差异是由传统玉米制成的大型玉米饼与Maseca的玉米饼，就像交换超市白面包，为一条全谷物酸味。香气，味道，甚至纹理是无与伦比的。如果你想了解原因，你可以：透明的采购是这个黄金时代的基石。
  2019年，Gaviria发布了一个15页的Masienda采购模式报告，其中包括其农民的影响分析，费用和肖像。 Gaviria股份，他预计他的2021份报告将在下个月发表。 “我们有建筑物，我们记录每年从每个社区购买多少玉米以在几年内了解基线，”他说。 “我们的企业兴趣不是过度来源，但是平衡我们所认为的是仍然允许个人提供当地社区的适当金额。”这是一个必要的检查，以保护精致的生态系统，确保未来不仅适用于传家宝玉米，而且为文化和社区而言。
  边境两侧的优质Masa的兴趣已经不断增长。在美国中的炸玉米饼书呆子渴望玉米饼被玉米饼被视为尊重它的多汁肉。但他们不得不等到2014年，看看玉米饼声明出现在高档餐厅菜单上，这是墨西哥厨师埃弗拉在纽约市的奥弗拉的宇宙的到来。

Nuñez和Hellman-Mass争夺了对奥斯汀的Tex-Mex预期的艰苦战斗，并且通过每盘不断旋转的Antojitos，就像他完美的三角形Tetelas装满了焖蔬菜一样，他在一个地区讲授了许多伟大的Masa的喜悦，更偏厚面粉玉米饼和脆脆的“硬壳”。荣誉涌入。2019年，粮食＆amp;葡萄酒在最好的新餐厅名单上放置在第二名。之后不久之后，新文章和公众注意力的波浪。随着需求不断增长，没有其他尼克萨尔在城镇，Nuñez和Hellman-群众有效地创造了德克萨斯州的一个新的玉米市场，现在他们正在延长本地供应可以允许的限制。 “德克萨斯州的玉米生长季节是疯狂的，”Nuñez继续。 “你只能在3月份在德克萨斯植物和收获玉米，这意味着你必须承诺并预测餐馆持续多年来的玉米。”
  出生于墨西哥东北部的Nuñez认为，它是关于尊重您墨西哥餐厅所在地区的全部。 “如果我们在墨西哥，我们可能会使用来自墨西哥的玉米，但我们不是 - 我们在奥斯汀。”
   对于最长的时间，公共需求和市场竞争推动了美国的Taqueros和Taqueras。使用最便宜的玉米饼可能。这导致了2美元的全能机构2美元，这是过去20年来统治泰格尼亚斯的玉米饼。有机玉米饼可以花费高达由Maseca制造的玉米饼的五倍，并且该数字仅在餐馆落后于手工玉米饼。结果是一个双重标准，使得一个制作炸玉米饼的想法，但也可以防止泰奎罗使用更好的成分并以可居住的价格销售炸玉米饼。当你在美丽的成分下放置玉米饼时，发生了奇怪的事情。在它是一个“小盘子”之前。现在它是“只是”炸玉米饼。在一个市场上，客户没有两次向一杯咖啡支付6美元或25美元的意大利面，为什么他们不愿花几美元用于用尤其是味道的星团玉米制成的炸玉米饼？
  好的Masa的高价与干玉米的物理沉重有很大关系，以及它在墨西哥南部最佳地增长。在全国成本上运送小型但重量的玉米汤。但除了制作更好的玉米饼外，雷奥洛姆玉米农民的购买为周围世界上第一个驯养作物之一的传统粮食道，为传统美食道带来了至关重要的支持。更重要的是，它还支持努力为几代种子挽救了那些种子的勤奋农民家庭，并帮助他们继续为您的所有锯齿状需求进行罕见的，美味的品种。
 与此同时，墨西哥和美国的低收入墨西哥人民不应该享用自己的烹饪遗产。真正的MASA革命需要考虑供应链中存在的不平等和剥削，并且必须保护这些社区与愤世厄姆玉米不断增长的需求。
 “使用有机玉米制作有机尼克萨马尔是我们将中指给一个占据我们文化存在的行业的方式，”Ricardo“Rick”Ortega说。他是L.A.第一个有机Tortillía，真理有机物的第一个有机粉碎的Cofounder。 Ortega和他的创业伙伴Omar Ahmed，于2014年开始他的革命性的Tortillía，作为抗拒城市的绅士化，这威胁要抹去他们的家乡的墨西哥遗产。艾哈迈德是第二代Tortillero。在他的家庭长玉米饼商店涌出回声公园之后，一个La邻居，在90年代的帮派暴力是一个温床，但现在是La最昂贵的，奥尔图拉和艾哈迈德汇集了他们的储蓄推出品牌，Nixtamizate在其他商店的设备上，在off-lock。
 大流行几乎迫使真相有机物永久地关闭玉米饼，但它几乎没有地。尽管迫切需要资本，但奥尔塔和艾哈迈德拒绝将玉米饼销售给标记其产品的零售地点。 “我想到了我的妈妈和我们的abuelas，”ortega说。他承认，他仍然用Guerrero Tortillas-A全国大众市场品牌捕捉他的父母，但他没有放弃。这种父母玉米饼叛国侵占了有机和雷奥拉姆玉米饼提出的挑战：“我们如何为我们的父母和Señoras制作足够的有机玉米饼？” ortega问道。 
正如ortega所说，Tortillerías就像他正在战斗长期战斗。 “良好的战斗”，因为他称之为。 “为了保持真正的玉米饼，靠近我们的心，让Masa掌握在手中。”

In the U.S., it’s never been easier to find tortillas that smell like fresh popcorn, taste like the earth, and support small family farms in Mexico. In  certain cities, you can buy a bag of fresh masa for homemade tacos as readily as you can find sliced bread. Just a few years ago, your only options for quality tortillas were to scour the web for “tortillerías nearby” or ask your favorite taquero where they got theirs. So how did we get here?
 “We’re in the era of third wave masa, and it’s been 100 years in the making,” Jorge Gaviria says, referring to a century of access to  nixtamalized masa in the United States culminating in our current golden age. As the cofounder of  Masienda, an importer of heirloom Mexican corn and high-quality tortilla equipment, he has earned the moniker of masa pioneer in the resurgence of premium masa. He likens the new demand for complex, aromatic, earthy Mexican corn to the  third wave specialty coffee movement’s impact on our coffee appetites. “Meticulous sourcing, single-origin, and geeking out about the process is now happening with masa,” he says. “It’s the same kind of framework.”
  The first wave of masa in the U.S. was all about convenience, starting with the invention of Maseca, the first instant masa flour, in 1941. In the decades that followed, a second wave of brick-and-mortar tortilla shops began in states with large Mexican immigrant populations. These tortillerías make decent masa out of American commodity field corn and have been the backbone of American barrios for generations.
  Masa’s third wave is all about seeking the most flavorful corn varieties from small growers across Mexico. Two brands—Masienda in the States and  Tamoa in Mexico—are shaping this new standard by lugging heavy sacks of really good-tasting corn from Mexico to the U.S., all in the name of serious tortillas. As of now, these are the only companies with sufficient connections to Mexican farmers to ensure a consistent supply of heirloom corn. But they’re not alone in building this wave. Tortillerías like  Three Sisters Nixtamal in Portland, Oregon, and  Kernel of Truth Organics in Los Angeles, as well as restaurants like  Suerte in Austin, are working with American farmers to make the best possible masa using domestic corn.
   The difference in flavor between true nixtamalized masa made from heirloom organic corn versus Maseca-based tortillas made from conventional corn is like swapping supermarket white bread for a hot loaf of whole grain sourdough. The aroma, flavor, and even texture is incomparable. If you want to understand why, you can: Transparent sourcing is a keystone of this golden age.
  In 2019, Gaviria published a  15-page report of Masienda’s sourcing model, which includes an impact analysis, expenses, and portraits of their farmers. Gaviria shares that he expects his 2021 report to be published in the next month. “We have structures in place where we document how much corn we are purchasing each year from each community to understand a baseline over the course of a few years,” he says. “Our corporate interest is not to over-source, but balancing what we believe is an appropriate amount that still allows for individuals to supply their local community.” It’s a necessary check to protect a delicate ecosystem, ensuring a future not just for heirloom corn, but also for the culture and community that make it possible.
  Appetites for quality masa on both sides of the border have been growing for years. Taco nerds in the U.S. have longed for a day where the tortilla was treated with as much respect as the juicy meat placed on it. But they had to wait until 2014 to see tortillas with an origin statement appear on an upscale restaurant menu, which came with the arrival of Mexican chef Enrique Olvera’s  Cosme in New York City.
  The idea behind Cosme’s handmade tortillas was to tell a story of Mexico with each bite. Olvera, the celebrated chef behind  Pujol in Mexico City and  Damian in Los Angeles, insisted on a whole masa  program, nixtamalizing masa for tortillas and training American servers on the subtleties of regional corn varieties. The corn itself came from Masienda, which sold its first sack of Mexican corn to Cosme in 2014, marking it as one of the first Mexican restaurants in America to use real Mexican corn. Cosme’s wild success sparked a new wave of interest in quality masa among the food-obsessed set. It also signaled to restaurant operators that despite the higher effort and cost, focusing on quality masa could be commercially viable. Masienda’s base of customers grew, quickly, expanding into the direct-to-consumer market with varieties like chalqueño blanco and easier-to-nixtamalize blue varieties.
 The tortillas were a hit. In his   New York Times review of Cosme in 2015, restaurant critic Pete Wells described the tortillas aroma as “completely wholesome—like flowers, bread straight from the oven, and a baby’s cheek at the same time.”
  In the years since, Masienda has contributed two further innovations to the golden age of masa. The first, the adorably named  Molinito, is a countertop mill that grinds tortillería-quality masa on demand. It’s the first machine of its kind designed for home or restaurant kitchens that uses stone in its grinding mechanism rather than metal burrs, essential to achieving the buttery-smooth quality of premium masa. Before the Molinito, you had to pay a lot of money to ship heavy portable grinders from Mexico or seek out hand-cranked manual grinders from mom-and-pop Mexican markets. While these types of metal grinders sufficed for the average home cook, there is something extra romantic about getting that immaculate Play-Doh that only stone grind wheels can provide. The second game changer, which, like the Molinito, came to market in 2020, is a  “chef grade” instant tortilla flour akin to Maseca, but made from heirloom corn varieties, just like Masienda’s fresh masa. As a just-add-water option, it’s a historic boon to serious home taqueros and corn nerds.
  At the same time, homegrown tortillerías around the country have been striving to make the best possible masa using American corn. Rather than relying on commodity dried field corn, enterprising tortillería owners have been connecting with growers of varieties native to Northern California and the Midwest. It turns out that corn grown according to American organic standards makes pretty great masa too.
  In Portland, Oregon, Adriana Azcárate-Ferbel and her husband, Pedro Ferbel-Azcárate, founded  Three Sisters Nixtamal in 2012, after getting tired of bringing back suitcases full of enchiladas Potosinas from Azcárate-Ferbel’s family’s home in Mexico’s state of San Luis Potosi. Azcárate-Ferbel committed to the painstaking process of showing local food lovers why they should care about the tortillas they used for their Tuesday taco nights. The couple showed up every week at Portland’s famous Saturday Farmers Market and free-sampled their way to a loyal customer base. Market goers were especially drawn to an eye-catching stack of marbled tortillas. The tortillas are made from a unique formula that Three Sisters Nixtamal created by carefully layering yellow, white, and blue corn masa batches with its red masa made with dried red chiles.
 “When we first started, you couldn’t even find American corn to nixtamalize!” Azcárate-Ferbel tells me in Español about her tortillería’s long journey. They wanted to get their corn as locally as possible, she says, but all the corn grown nearby in California and Washington was either a sweet corn variety or lower quality corn for animal feed. “The only organic corn that farmers were growing back then was used to feed their animals. It was hard at first.” Azcárate-Ferbel remembers vividly when she saw her first sack of Masienda corn in 2015. She was mesmerized by the sheer existence of heirloom Mexican corn in the States. “But it was $5 a pound just to buy the corn,” she continues, “and by the time you added labor and equipment cost to nixtamalize, we couldn’t afford it.” So they went their own way with American-grown field corn from Northern California, which was the most local the couple could find back then. In 2021, they are still committed to masa education, and you can still find their stand’s vendors slicing masa to make freshly puffed tortillas for curious passersby to try at the farmers market. Their tortillas are now in many co-ops and supermarkets along the Pacific Northwest too.
 In Austin, Texas, Fermín Nuñez of  Suerte has made his own contribution to the country’s tortilla renaissance in the form of outrageously delicious tacos on tortillas made from local corn. “Suerte came about after being obsessed with making tacos out of central Texan corn,” Nuñez says. His obsession began with a serendipitous blob of masa that his future business partner, Sam Hellman-Mass, nixtamalized from Texas corn. “By luck, a well-known farmer here in Austin gave Sam some of his quality corn grown the right way that he usually fed his pigs with, and we opened Suerte, chasing that perfect tortilla since then.”
  Nuñez and Hellman-Mass fought the uphill battle against Austin’s Tex-Mex expectations, and through each plate of constantly revolving antojitos, like his perfect triangular tetelas filled with braised greens, he’s taught many the joy of great masa in a region more partial to thick  flour tortillas and crunchy “hard shells.” The accolades came pouring in. In 2019,  Food & Wine placed it at number two on its  Best New Restaurant list. Waves of new articles and public attention followed shortly after. With growing demand and no other nixtamal of that quality in town, Nuñez and Hellman-Mass effectively created a new corn market in Texas, and they are now stretching the limits of what the local supply can allow. “The corn growing season in Texas is crazy,” Nuñez continues. “You can only plant and harvest corn in Texas in March, so that means that you gotta commit to and predict how much corn the restaurant will go through the following year.”
  Nuñez, who was born in northeast Mexico, believes that it’s all about respecting the region where your Mexican restaurant is located. “If we were in Mexico, we would probably use corn from Mexico, but we’re not—we’re in Austin.”
   For the longest time, public demand and market competition has pushed taqueros and taqueras in the U.S. to use the least expensive tortillas possible. This led to the almighty institution of $2 tacos that has dominated taquerías for the past 20 years. Organic tortillas can cost up to five times that of tortillas made from Maseca, and that figure only rises for handmade tortillas at restaurants. The result is a double standard that venerates the idea of a well-made taco, but also prevents the taquero from using better ingredients and selling tacos at a livable price. Something weird happens when you place a tortilla under beautiful ingredients. Before it was a “small plate.” Now it’s “just” a taco. In a market where customers don’t think twice about paying $6 for a cup of coffee or $25 for a bowl of pasta, why are they unwilling to spend a few more dollars for a taco made with especially flavorful heirloom corn?
  The high price of good masa has a lot to do with the physical heaviness of dried corn, and the fact that it grows best in the southern parts of Mexico. Transporting small-but-weighty batches of corn across the country costs money. But besides making for better tortillas, buying from heirloom corn farmers brings crucial support to traditional foodways surrounding one of the world’s first domesticated crops. More important, it also supports the hardworking farming families who have saved those seeds for generations and helps them continue to grow rare, flavorful varieties for all your taco-nerding needs.
 At the same time, low-income Mexican people in Mexico and the U.S. shouldn’t be priced out of their own culinary heritage. A true masa revolution needs to account for the inequalities and exploitation that exist in the supply chain, and it must protect those communities in relation to the growing demand for heirloom corn.
 “Making organic nixtamal using organic corn was our way of giving the middle finger to an industry that took so much of our cultural existence,” Ricardo “Rick” Ortega says. He is the cofounder of L.A.’s first organic tortillería,  Kernel of Truth Organics. Ortega and his founding business partner, Omar Ahmed, started his revolutionary tortillería in 2014 as a stand against the city’s gentrification, which threatens to erase their hometown’s Mexican heritage. Ahmed is a second-generation tortillero. After his family’s longstanding tortilla shop was gentrified out of Echo Park, an L.A. neighborhood that was a hotbed for gang violence in the ’90s but is now one of L.A.’s most expensive, Ortega and Ahmed pooled their savings to launch the brand, nixtamalizing on other shops’ equipment in off-hours.
 The pandemic nearly forced Kernel of Truth Organics to shut down its tortilla-making permanently, but it barely ground by. Despite an urgent need for capital, Ortega and Ahmed refuse to sell tortillas to retail locations that mark up their products. “I think about my mom and our abuelas,” Ortega says. He admits that he still catches his parents with Guerrero tortillas—a national mass-market brand—in their refrigerator, but he is not giving up. This parental tortilla treason encapsulates the challenge posed by organic and heirloom corn tortillas: “How can we make these organic tortillas affordable enough for our parents and señoras?” Ortega asks.
  As Ortega says, tortillerías like his are fighting the long fight. “The good fight,” as he calls it. “To keep true tortillas close to our hearts and to keep masa in our hands.”
title: 欢迎来到Masa的黄金时代
title_en: Welcome to the Golden Age of Masa

note:
2006年，Redfin是第一家在地图上放置房屋的公司。这是甚至在谷歌地图是一个表演平台之前。他们在2008年迁移到谷歌地图之前，他们使用了Microsoft虚拟地球。这是普罗特施机的传奇成就，大量赋予购房者自己购物。从那以后，高质量的地图浏览一直是任何房地产购物工具的表格赌注。
 进入Q2，Opendoor的地图正在具有性能问题。当用户在Phoenix中查看家园时，在地图上看到任何内容之前，它可能需要15秒。
  在我们开始优化地图速度之前，我们需要弄清楚为什么它感到慢。经过一些与Chrome Dev Tools的分析，显而易见的是，对我们REST API进行了缓慢的调用来获取房产列表数据以在地图上显示。正在寻找DataDog向我们展示了这次大部分时间在ActiveModelserializers中花费并从DB获取。然后，我们构建了一个捕获用户疼痛的度量标准，我们想要解决：P90时间来获取地图的属性数据。我们使用第90个百分位数来捕获主要用户体验，同时排除异常值。
   10.54s p90至＆lt; 1s p90优化发生在5份大约1个份：
   我们使用Rails Active_Model_Serializers描述REST API将返回的字段。 Rails应用程序中的常见问题是用于多个端点的串行器，并且嵌入到包含多个使用情况所需的字段。这导致从我们的API和备用数据库中的数据过度取出（我们在MongoDB中存储列表）。我们还更新了我们的Mongoid查询以使用预测仅返回完成MongoDB的请求所需的数据。仅为地图组件创建专用序列化器并减少数据提取解决了这些问题，并让我们几乎是2倍的加速。
 Rails应用程序中的常见问题是用于多个端点的串行器，并且嵌入到包含多个使用情况所需的字段。
   在修复DB问题时，我们注意到，当前端请求未过滤的区域的属性列表时，我们注意到我们具有智能逻辑以缓存序列化属性列表。这是最常见的查询类型，因为它是用户在地图上登陆时的默认状态。不幸的是，在所有情况下，都会引入错误的错误。我们纠正了此行为，并在端点周围添加了集成测试，以确保填充缓存，然后按后的请求。延迟尖峰和缓存命中率的警报将捕获并标记我们以调查产品中的缓存系统故障（更详细信息）。 
DataDog在我们的Serializers和Mongo之间表现出很多回圈。事实证明，通过在其中一个序列化程序字段中进行序列化属性列表，其中一个字段中的一个字段通过在其中一个序列化程序字段中添加了n + 1查询。在查询数据库的属性时，我们通过使用mongoid的包含（）来完成此操作。优化查询，以便在序列化之前批量获取所有数据，以越来越几秒钟。
  地图上的属性和列表中的属性都由相同的查询获取。如果属性出现在列表和地图中，则这是一个设计决策，使逻辑简单，并最小化有效载荷大小。分析显示有效载荷大小并不是一个问题，但每个列表都需要自己的CloudSearch和数据库查询。将这些分为两个与前端并行完成的两个单独的API调用是一场轻松的胜利，并且不需要任何在轨道中具有多线程的遇到。
  我们的最终胜利完全来自避免了数据库。通常，我们从CloudSearch获取房产列表，然后用MongoDB的一些额外的字段来水合物。相反，我们将前端切换到仅期望纬度/经度点位置，并且如果有超过120个属性来显示纬度/经度点位置并显示群集。这意味着当点集群显示我们不必触摸MongoDB时，在我们做的情况下，它是少数属性和相对较快的。
  最后一步是确保我们有一种捕获回归的好方法。虽然自动化测试对于在代码级别捕获错误时，警报很重要，因为微妙的配置更改可以在暂存环境中自动测试的方式打破分布式系统（如缓存）可能不会捕获。我们现在在有一个异常的延迟变化时由DataDog通知，并且我们有具有相关指标的有用仪表板。
    因此，我们从家庭购物工具中看到了卓越的表现，并且可以更快地采用Opendoor-Backed优惠，这是一款支持我们买家的家庭优惠的产品，并在今天的热门市场中给予他们竞争优势。 Web和Mobile的性能工作是我和我的团队的首要任务。我们将继续将资源投入资源进入我们家庭购物工具，其目标是为客户提供最佳体验。

note_en:
In 2006, Redfin was the first company to put homes on a map⁰. This was even before Google Maps was a performant platform. They launched with Microsoft Virtual Earth before migrating to Google Maps in 2008¹. This was a legendary achievement in proptech, massively empowering homebuyers to shop on their own. Ever since, high quality map browsing has been table stakes for any real estate shopping tool.
 Going into Q2, the maps on Opendoor were having performance issues. When a user viewed  homes in Phoenix, it could take 15+ seconds before they see anything on the map.
  Before we could start optimizing map speed, we needed to figure out why it felt slow. After some profiling with Chrome dev tools, it became apparent that there was a slow call to our REST API to fetch the property listing data to display on the map. Looking further, Datadog showed us that the bulk of this time was spent in ActiveModelSerializers and fetching from the DB. We then constructed a metric that captured the user pain we wanted to address: p90 time to fetch property data for the map. We use a 90th percentile to capture the predominant user experience while excluding outliers.
   The 10.54s p90 to <1s p90 optimization happened in 5 parts over about 1 month:
   We use Rails  active_model_serializers to describe the fields that the REST API will return. A common problem in Rails apps is the same serializer being used for multiple endpoints and bloating to contain fields needed for multiple use-cases. This causes over-fetching of data both from our APIs and from the backing DB (we store listings in MongoDB). We also updated our  Mongoid queries to use  projections to return only the data necessary to fulfill the request from MongoDB. Creating specialized serializers just for the map component and reducing data fetches solved these issues and got us nearly a 2x speedup.
 A common problem in Rails apps is the same serializer being used for multiple endpoints and bloating to contain fields needed for multiple use-cases.
   While fixing the DB problem, we noticed that we had smart logic in place to cache the serialized list of properties when the front-end requested an unfiltered list of properties for a region. This is the most common type of query because it’s the default state when a user lands on a map. Unfortunately a bug had been introduced that turned off this caching behavior in all cases. We corrected this behavior and added integration tests around the endpoint to ensure the cache is populated, then hit on subsequent requests. Alerts on latency spikes and cache hit rate will catch and flag us to investigate caching system failures in prod (more on that below).
  Datadog showed a lot of bouncing around between our serializers and mongo. It turned out that one of the fields had added an n+1 query by doing a fetch in one of the serializer fields as it was serializing a list of properties. We did this by using  Mongoid’s includes() when querying for properties from the database. Optimizing queries so that all data was fetched in bulk before anything was serialized won us a few more seconds.
  Both the properties on the map and the properties in the list were fetched by the same query. This was a design decision made to keep the logic simple and minimize the payload size if a property appears in both the list and the map. Profiling revealed that payload size wasn’t really an issue, but each list required its own CloudSearch and database query. Splitting these into two separate API calls done in parallel from the front-end was an easy win and didn’t require any encounters with multi-threading in Rails.
  Our final win came from avoiding the database entirely on some requests. Normally we fetch property listings from CloudSearch then hydrate them with a few extra fields from MongoDB. Instead, we switched the front-end to only expect latitude/longitude point locations and display clusters if there are more than 120 properties to show. This means that when point clusters are showing we don’t have to touch MongoDB, and in the cases we do, it’s a small number of properties and relatively quick.
  The final step was ensuring we have a great way to catch regressions. While automated tests are useful to catch bugs at the code level, alerting is important because subtle config changes can break distributed systems (like the cache) in ways automated testing in a staging environment may not catch. We now get notified by Datadog when there’s an anomalous latency change and we have useful dashboards with associated metrics.
    As a result, we’re seeing great performance from our home shopping tools and have seen even faster adoption of  Opendoor-Backed Offers, an offering that backs our buyers’ home offers with all cash to give them a competitive edge in today’s hot market. Performance work on web and mobile is a top priority for me and my team. We will continue investing resources into our home shopping tools with the goal of delivering the best experience possible to our customers.
 If this type of work sounds interesting, Opendoor is hiring! Head to our   careers page  to learn more.

note_en:
Patrick Doherty had always been very active. He trekked the Himalayas and hiked trails in Spain.
  But about a year and a half ago, he noticed pins and needles in his fingers and toes. His feet got cold. And then he started getting out of breath any time he walked his dog up the hills of County Donegal in Ireland where he lives.
  "I noticed on some of the larger hill climbs I was getting a bit breathless," says Doherty, 65. "So I realized something was wrong."
  Doherty found out he had a rare, but devastating inherited disease — known as  transthyretin amyloidosis — that had killed his father. A misshapen protein was building up in his body, destroying important tissues, such as nerves in his hands and feet and his heart.
    "It's terrible prognosis," Doherty says. "This is a condition that deteriorates very rapidly. It's just dreadful."
  So Doherty was thrilled when he found out that doctors were testing a new way to try to treat amyloidosis. The approach used a revolutionary gene-editing technique called  CRISPR, which allows scientists to make very precise changes in DNA.
      On Saturday, researchers reported the first data indicating that the experimental treatment worked, causing levels of the destructive protein to plummet in Doherty's body and the bodies of five other patients treated with the approach.
    The advance is being hailed not just for amyloidosis patients but also as a proof-of-concept that CRISPR could be used to treat many other, much more common diseases. It's a new way of using the innovative technology.
  "This is a major milestone for patients," says  Jennifer Doudna of the University of California, Berkeley, who shared a Nobel Prize for her work helping develop CRISPR.
  "While these are early data, they show us that we can overcome one of the biggest challenges with applying CRISPR clinically so far, which is being able to deliver it systemically and get it to the right place," Doudna says.
  CRISPR has already been shown to help patients suffering from the devastating blood disorders  sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia. And doctors are trying to use it to treat cancer and to  restore vision to people blinded by a rare genetic disorder.
  But those experiments involve taking cells out of the body, editing them in the lab, and infusing them back in or injecting CRISPR directly into cells that need fixing.
    The study Doherty volunteered for is the first in which doctors are simply infusing the gene-editor directly into patients and letting it find its own way to the right gene in the right cells. In this case, it's cells in the liver making the destructive protein.
  "This is the first example in which CRISPR-Cas9 is injected directly into the bloodstream — in other words systemic administration — where we use it as a way to reach a tissue that's far away from the site of injection and very specifically use it to edit disease-causing genes," says John Leonard, the CEO of  Intellia Therapeutics, which is sponsoring the study.
  Doctors infused billions of microscopic structures known as nanoparticles carrying genetic instructions for the CRISPR gene-editor into four patients in London and two in New Zealand. The nanoparticles were absorbed by their livers, where they unleashed armies of CRISPR gene-editors. The CRISPR editor homed in on the target gene in the liver  and sliced it, disabling production of the destructive protein.
  Within weeks, the levels of protein causing the disease plummeted, especially in the volunteers who received a higher dose. Researchers reported at the  Peripheral Nerve Society Annual Meeting and in a  paper published in  The New England Journal of Medicine.
  "It really is exciting," says Dr.  Julian Gillmore, who is leading the study at the University College London, Royal Free Hospital.
  "This has the potential to completely revolutionize the outcome for these patients who have lived with this disease in their family for many generations. It's decimated some families that I've been looking after. So this is amazing," Gillmore says.
  The patients will have to be followed longer, and more patients will have to be treated, to make sure the treatment's safe, and determine how much it's helping, Gillmore stresses. But the approach could help those struck by amyloidosis that isn't inherited, which is a far more common version of the disease, he says.
  Moreover, the promising results potentially open the door for using the same approach to treatment of many other, more common diseases for which taking cells out of the body or directly injecting CRISPR isn't realistic, including heart disease, muscular dystrophy and brain diseases such as Alzheimer's.
  "This is really opening a new era as we think about gene-editing where we can begin to think about accessing all kinds of different tissue in the body via systemic administration," Leonard says.
    "This is a wonderful day for the future of gene-editing as a medicine,"  agree  Fyodor Urnov, a professor of genetics at the University of California, Berkeley. "We as a species are watching this remarkable new show called: our gene-edited future."
  Doherty says he started feeling better within weeks of the treatment and has continued to improve in the weeks since then.
  "I definitely feel better," he told NPR. "I'm speaking to you from upstairs in our house. I climbed stairs to get up here. I would have been feeling breathless. I'm thrilled."

Van Gogh冒险是Martin Bailey，我们的长期记者和艺术家专家的每周博客。每周五发布，他的故事将根据他自己的细致调查和发现，他的故事范围从新闻中的关于这个最有趣的艺术家到学术作品。
  首次再现在这里：Vincent的村庄设计的三人草图设计为书签
 梵高的最不寻常的作品之一刚刚出现了三个未知的农民草图。它们是在薄的垂直纸条上绘制，一种艺术家选择的好奇格式。在法国农民的一部小说中发现了图纸，纸张与本书完全相同。
 这三个草图是第一次由艺术报纸复制。在十年中发现完全未知的梵高图纸现在罕见或两次。该片刚刚在阿姆斯特丹的Van Gogh博物馆展出，在此次收购的新展览中，这里留下来（直到9月12日）。虽然它在展会中呈现，但只有三个草图，艺术品几乎肯定提供了意想不到的目的。
    阿姆斯特丹博物馆的高级研究员Teio Meedendorp告诉我们：“我相信它被作为书签。除非有一个原因，否则在这种配置中绘制三个草图会很奇怪，并且它在被发现的书中贴心地舒服。“
    Vincent是一个狂热的读者，给了他对荷兰艺术家朋友Anthon Van Rappard的法国农民的一部小说。他在1883年6月15日写给van Rappard，他说他将在UTRECHT发布一揽子，用印刷品和一本书，由法国作家埃米尔埃克尔曼和亚历山大·钟师的书，他大钦佩。 Histoired d'联合国Paysan通过Alsace农民的眼睛讲述了法国革命的故事。文森特通过ThéophileSchuler说明，向他的朋友向他的朋友提供了“我认为你会发现Erckmann-Chatrian美丽”。
    van rappard于1892年去世，达到了33岁，然后将其妻子亨里雅特特传递给了1910年的妻子亨利蒂斯，曾与书签一起致力于她的家庭悄然保存，直到2019年私人销售到梵高博物馆。 
铅笔图形是原油，因为他们在文森特出发后很快就完成了艺术家，但他们很重要，因为他早期的非正式草图生存了很少。风格主义性地，他们可以在1881年秋季日期，当他住在他的父母的Etten村，对工作中当地农民的数字深感很感兴趣。
 直到两年后，Vincent向Van Rappard发送了Histoire d'联合国Paysan，这表明书签在小说中忘记了，当他包裹包裹时没有被注意到。如果文森特已经出示给Van Rappard一些草图，他将更有可能发送最近的速度，以证明他的艺术是如何发展的。
 在28厘米高的书签上，上素描显示了一个由恐怖树行走的女人。中间人描绘了一个坐着的人旁边，一个坐着的人在火灾旁边描绘了一个清醒的工作，让人想起了1881年11月的van Gogh，逃火的老人（现在Kröller-Müller博物馆，Otterlo）。较低的草图描绘了一个女人的概况。 Van Gogh可能已经看到这些数字松散地说明了Erckmann-Chatrian小说。
    本书的前部签署了“文森特”。他把这本书寄给了Van Rappard“读书”，目前尚不清楚签名是否表明这是礼物，或者是一个礼貌提醒，这是贷款，应该退还。
    10月，在送书之后的一年中，Van Rappard访问了Nuenen的文森特 - 但没有回到这本书。在访问van gogh期间，勾勒出他的朋友的肖像，是他整个Oeuvre中最大的绘制肖像。只有工作的上半部分才能存活。
 遗憾的是，在100月1885年5月，他们的友谊在Vincent的唯一石英仪录音机批判后，他们在1885年5月突然结束了，这描绘了他对马铃薯食鸟的绘画。愤怒，愤怒地贬低了肖像，整齐地切成两半。下半场已经丢失了，但他很快就重复了上半部分的反面，使一对妇女和一个携带一束木头的男人的粗略草图。
 由于这种回收，van Rappard肖像的最重要的一半，凭借眼睛，在他的荷兰艺术年内van Gogh最亲近的友谊已经挽救了豪华的证据。 
•克里斯蒂是在6月30日在伦敦销售伦敦马铃薯收割机（Aardappelroier）的图画，估计为300,000英镑至500,000英镑。从荷兰南部的村庄努努恩举行的纽伦森，从6月至7月开始约会。叉在手中，农民正在吸烟时挖土豆。马铃薯收割机最初由杰出的荷兰艺术史学家H.P。不明白。
    •向日葵（1888年8月）本周回到了伦敦，成为全国画廊绘画向日本和澳大利亚的博览会之后的明星景点。在堪培拉国家澳大利亚国家美术馆，201,000人在15周的运行期间看到了61次作品的展览。使用Covid-19，这可能是世界上最好的2020-21次展览中的等级。

Adventures with Van Gogh is a weekly blog by Martin Bailey, our long-standing correspondent and expert on the artist. Published every Friday, his stories will range from newsy items about this most intriguing artist to scholarly pieces based on his own meticulous investigations and discoveries.
  Reproduced here for the first time: a trio of sketches from Vincent’s village—designed as a bookmark
 One of Van Gogh’s most unusual artworks has just emerged—three unknown sketches of peasants. They are drawn on a thin vertical strip of paper, a curious format for an artist to choose. The drawings were found in a novel on the French peasantry and the paper is exactly the same height as the book.
 The three sketches are reproduced by  The Art Newspaper here for the first time. Discoveries of totally unknown Van Gogh drawings are now rare—perhaps once or twice in a decade. The sheet has just gone on display at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, in a new exhibition on acquisitions,   Here to Stay (until 12 September). Although it is presented in the show as simply a trio of sketches, the artwork almost certainly served an unexpected purpose.
    Teio Meedendorp, a senior researcher at the Amsterdam museum, told us: “I believe that it was made as a bookmark. It would be curious to draw three sketches in this configuration unless there was a reason, and it fits snugly inside the book in which it was found.”
    Vincent, an avid reader, gave his copy of a novel on the French peasantry to his Dutch artist friend Anthon van Rappard. Writing to Van Rappard on 15 June 1883, he said he would be posting a package to him in Utrecht, with prints and a book by the French writers Emile Erckmann and Alexandre Chatrian, whom he greatly admired.  Histoire d’un Paysan recounts the story of the French Revolution through the eyes of an Alsace peasant. Illustrated by Théophile Schuler, Vincent assured his friend that “I do think you’ll find the Erckmann-Chatrian beautiful”.
    Van Rappard died in 1892, aged just 33, and the book then passed to his wife Henriëtte, who lived until 1910.  Histoire d’un Paysan, together with the bookmark, was quietly preserved by her family until 2019, when both were privately sold to the Van Gogh Museum.
 The pencil drawings are crude, since they were done soon after Vincent set out to become an artist, but they are important since so few of his early informal sketches survive. Stylistically, they can be dated to autumn 1881, when he was living in his parent’s village of Etten and was deeply interested in capturing figures of the local peasants at work.
 It was not until two years later that Vincent sent  Histoire d’un Paysan to Van Rappard, suggesting that the bookmark had lain forgotten in the novel and was not noticed when he wrapped up the package. If Vincent had set out to give Van Rappard a few sketches, he would have been much more likely to have sent very recent ones, to demonstrate how his art was developing.
 On the 28cm-high bookmark, the upper sketch shows a woman walking by a pollarded tree. The middle one portrays a seated man beside a fire, a work reminiscent of a finished drawing which Van Gogh made in November 1881,   Old Man at the Fireside  (now Kröller-Müller Museum, Otterlo). The lower sketch depicts a woman in profile. Van Gogh may well have seen the figures as loosely illustrating the Erckmann-Chatrian novel.
    The front of the book is signed “Vincent”. He had sent the book to Van Rappard “to read” and it is unclear whether the signature indicates that it was a gift or was a polite reminder that it was a loan and should be returned.
    In October, just over year after sending the book, Van Rappard visited Vincent in Nuenen—but without returning the book. During the visit Van Gogh sketched a portrait of his friend, the largest drawn portrait in his entire oeuvre. Only the top half of the work survives.
 Sadly, their friendship came to an abrupt end in May 1885, after Van Rappard wrote critically about Vincent’s only  lithograph, which depicted his painting of  The Potato Eaters. Vincent, who was furious, dismembered the portrait, neatly slicing it in half. The bottom half has been lost, but he soon reused the reverse of the top half to make rough sketches of a pair of women and a man carrying a bundle of wood.
 Thanks to this recycling, the most important half of the Van Rappard portrait, with the eyes, has been saved—poignant evidence of Van Gogh’s closest friendship during his Dutch artistic years.
  • Christie’s is to sell a drawing of   The Potato Harvester (Aardappelrooier)  in London on 30 June, estimated at £300,000-£500,000. Dating from June-July 1885, it was done in Nuenen, the village in the south of the Netherlands. Fork in hand, the peasant is digging up potatoes, while smoking his pipe.  The Potato Harvester was originally owned by the distinguished Dutch art historian H.P. Bremmer.
    • The  Sunflowers (August 1888) is back in London this week, after being the star attraction for a tour of the National Gallery’s paintings to Japan and Australia. At the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra the exhibition of 61 works was seen by 201,000 people during its 15-week run. With Covid-19, this is likely to rank among the world’s best-attended 2020-21 exhibitions.
    Martin Bailey is a leading Van Gogh specialist and investigative reporter for  The Art Newspaper. Bailey has curated Van Gogh exhibitions at the Barbican Art Gallery and Compton Verney/National Gallery of Scotland. He was a co-curator of Tate Britain’s  The EY Exhibition: Van Gogh and Britain (27 March-11 August 2019). He has written a number of bestselling books, including  The Sunflowers Are Mine: The Story of Van Gogh's Masterpiece (Frances Lincoln 2013, available in the  UK and  US),  Studio of the South: Van Gogh in Provence (Frances Lincoln 2016, available in the  UK and  US) and  Starry Night: Van Gogh at the Asylum (White Lion Publishing 2018, available in the  UK and  US). Bailey's  Living with Vincent van Gogh: The Homes & Landscapes that Shaped the Artist (White Lion Publishing 2019, available in the  UK and  US) provides an overview of the artist’s life. His latest publication is the reissued book  The Illustrated Provence Letters of Van Gogh (Batsford 2021, available in the  UK and  US).
